data.Name: Basic Rock Properties
data.Description: Basic Rock Properties are the result of basic analysis typically performed on rock samples before performing more advanced measurements. This category includes a suite often called "Routine Core Analysis", which is typically for conventional rocks like sandstone, but also basic analysis (like Crushed Rock Analysis) done on unconventional rocks like shale. This suite is characterized by measuring Porosity, Permeability, Density, and/or Saturation with a specific and basic set of methods.

data.Name: Capillary Pressure
data.Description: Capillary pressure defines the fluid distribution within a porous media.  It measures the difference in pressure across the interface between two phases, which are typically oil/water, gas/water or gas/oil.

data.Name: Electrical Properties
data.Description: Measurements of the electrical properties of rock provide fundamental input to calibrate and interpret resistivity log measurements for water saturation interpretation. The primary electrical property tests are: formation resistivity factor (F or FRF), resistivity index (I) and cation-exchange capacity tests (wet chemistry CEC and multiple salinity Qv methods). These data are applied in fluid saturation models.

data.Name: Extraction
data.Description: Data related to the separation of a liquid (e.g. oil, water) from a rock sample. Data typically include weight/mass of the samples and methods of extraction.

data.Name: Flow Assurance
data.Description: Properties related to the prevention of scales, hydrates, asphaltene and paraffin deposits and other problems that could stop flow of fluid from the subsurface, wellhead or pipeline.

data.Name: Fluid Inclusion
data.Description: This analysis family is used to identify any data associated with single fluid inclusions or fluid inclusion assemblages from a rock sample. Fluid inclusions are small bubbles of liquid that can become trapped within a crystal, or along healed crystal fractures. The properties of these inclusions can be used to infer the properties of reservoired or migrating fluids through time.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Gas Chromatography
data.Description: Two-dimensional gas chromatography (GC×GC) is a multidimensional gas chromatography technique that utilizes two chromatographic columns with different stationary phases. In GC×GC, all of the effluent from the first dimension column is diverted to the second dimension column via a modulator. The modulator quickly traps, then "injects" the effluent from the first dimension column onto the second dimension. This process creates a retention plane of the 1st dimension separation x 2nd dimension separation.

data.Name: Gamma Ray
data.Description: Measurements of gamma radioactivity on a rock specimen.

data.Name: Isotope
data.Description: Isotope analysis is the identification of isotopic signature, abundance of isotopes of chemical elements (including, but not limited to, C,H,O,N,S) within organic and inorganic compounds. Isotope ratios are measured using mass spectrometry, which separates the different isotopes of an element on the basis of their mass-to-charge ratio. Isotope compositions are expressed as delta values (δ) in permil (‰), i.e. parts per thousand differences relative to a standard. The standard should be specified as part of the data record.

data.Name: PVT
data.Description: Analysis of the effect of pressure, volume, and temperature on the fluid properties.

data.Name: Water Analysis
data.Description: Analysis of the properties of a water sample and substances found in a water sample.

data.Name: Fractionation
data.Description: Fractionation is the separation of the component parts, or fractions, of petroleum according to boiling point (distillation), polarity (SARA), molecular size (mole sieve) or other differentiating properties.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography
data.Description: Gas chromatography (GC) is the process of separating compounds in a mixture by injecting a gaseous or liquid sample into a mobile phase, typically called the carrier gas, and passing the gas through a stationary phase. The mobile phase is usually an inert gas or unreactive gas such as helium, argon, nitrogen or hydrogen. The stationary phase is contained inside of a separation column. Today, most GC columns are fused silica capillaries with an inner diameter of 100-320 μm and a length of 5-60 m. The GC column is located inside an oven where the temperature of the gas can be controlled and the effluent coming off the column is monitored by a suitable detector as a function of retention time.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy
data.Description: GasChromatographyMassSpectroscopy (GCMS) is composed of two major building blocks: the gas chromatograph (GC) and the mass spectrometer (MS). The GC separates molecules in a mixture based on their relative affinity for the stationary phase of the column. Each GC peak elutes (comes off) from the column at different times (called the retention time), this allows the mass spectrometer downstream to capture, ionize, accelerate, deflect, and detect the ionized molecules separately. These two components, used together, allow a much finer degree of substance identification than than gas chromatography or mass spectrometry alone.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy Mass Spectroscopy
data.Description: Gas Chromatography–Tandem Mass spectrometry (GC-MS-MS) couples a Gas Chromatograph (GC) with two Mass Spectrometers which increases detail in molecular structure analysis. This Family includes QQQ and MRM (Multiple-reaction Monitoring).

data.Name: Pyrolysis
data.Description: Pyrolysis is the thermal decomposition of materials at elevated temperatures, often in an inert atmosphere. In petroleum analysis, pyrolysis is the heating of an organic material, such as an oil or organic rich rock, in the absence of oxygen. Note that in practice, pyrolysis is sometimes used in combination with some other method to separate compounds. In OSDU, Pyrolysis (Py)-GC or PyGCMS are handled under the GC and GCMS analysis types. Bulk pyrolysis (e.g., RockEval) and kinetics measurements are grouped in this analysis type.

data.Name: Relative Permeability
data.Description: Relative permeability is the ratio of a secondary phase (gas, oil, or water) to a reference permeability (usually absolute permeability). This experiment can be conducted at varying saturations of the secondary fluid phase or at a single irreducible saturation of the second phase.

data.Name: Elemental Composition
data.Description: The goal of elemental composition analysis is understand the chemical make-up of a sample. Typically measured on either rock or fluid samples. Since WaterAnalysis is separate, note here that Water Analysis and composition is handled separately.

data.Name: Geomechanics
data.Description: Geomechanics core analysis measures the mechanical properties of rocks and fractures - elasticity, strength, and physical properties related to deformation such as thermal expansion and fracture conductivity.

data.Name: Mineralogy
data.Description: Mineralogy incorporates all aspects of minerals within rocks, including physical properties, chemical composition, internal crystal structures using analysis like XRD, FTIR, PointCounting, etc…

data.Name: Brine Permeability
data.Description: Permeability of a rock sample to brine (salt water similar to formation water or injection water); These experiments are typically carried out at several flow rates using simulated formation water.

data.Name: Petrography
data.Description: Organic petrography is the microscopic study of organic constituents found in coal, carbon, shales, and other geological samples.

data.Name: NMR
data.Description:
Also known as Nuclear Magnetic Resonance. NMR measures the relaxation of hydrogen protons using low field electromagnetic waves. This can be conducted on brine-saturated or desaturated samples. 

NMR can include porosity, bound fluid, clay volume, bound water, T1/T2 maps, T2D, total water saturation, capillary bound water, SWIRR (irreducible water saturation), interpreted perm, and pore size distribution.

NMR in the Sample Analysis refers to lab NMR. When NMR is measured on a physical sample retrieved from the wellbore, it is lab NMR and is captured under Sample Analysis. When NMR is measured in the borehole, it is log NMR, and is captured as a Well Log in OSDU.

data.Name: Grain Size Analysis
data.Description: Grain Size Analysis is used to determine the percentage of each size of a grain that is in the sample.

data.Name: Stratigraphy
data.Description: Subdivision of rock strata to provide ages and order of lithological sequences

data.Name: Wettability
data.Description: Wettability is the ability of one fluid to spread on or adhere to (that is, maintain contact with) a solid surface in the presence of other immiscible fluids. Typically, this is measured as water/oil interaction with a rock sample.

data.Name: Core Description
data.Description: Written and/or diagrammatic representation of the core to describe the lithologies, minerals, fractures, fossils, and structure of the core
